ITV1's financial thriller Wired lost 800,000 viewers on its second outing last night, Monday October 20, and was beaten by a repeat of BBC1's Traffic Cops.

The drama about a banking fraud pulled in 4 million viewers and an 18% share in the 9pm hour, down from last week's 4.8 million and 21%, according to unofficial overnight figures.

BBC1's repeated documentary series about Humberside's traffic police pulled in 4.5 million viewers and a 20% share across an hour from 9pm.

The final part of Amazon with Bruce Parry drew 2.9 million viewers and a 13% share between 9pm and 10pm on BBC2, down 100,000 on last week.

Channel 4's Extraordinary Animals in the Womb attracted 1.5 million viewers and a 7% share between 9pm and 10.35pm, with a further 177,000 on Channel 4 +1.

The third part of Channel Five's Unbreakable picked up 700,000 viewers and a 3% share in the 9pm hour - down 100,000 on last week.

BBC1's Panorama on Russia pulled in 2.4 million viewers and a 10% share between 8pm and 8.30pm - the same as the final part of BBC2's What to Eat Now.

ITV1's Coronation Street won the slot with 9.3 million viewers and a 39% share.

BBC1 won the 10pm slot with its news picking up 4.5 million viewers and a 24% share over 25 minutes. ITV1's News at Ten drew 2 million and an 11% share over 30 minutes.

BBC2's repeat of Have I Got News for You pulled in 1.8 million viewers and a 10% share between 10pm and 10.30pm, while Five's repeat of Paul Merton in India drew 800,000 and 5% between 10pm and 11.05pm.

The executive producer of hit BBC2 show Tribe is being tipped as the leading candidate to become BBC4 controller.

The BBC independent head of knowledge commissioning, Richard Klein, is among the contenders to take over following the appointment of Janice Hadlow as BBC2 controller.

During his time at the BBC, Klein has commissioned numerous successful and critically acclaimed shows - from BBC1's Traffic Cops to BBC2's White season.

A former commissioning editor for documentaries, successes under his tenure included BBC1's Bafta award-winning Evicted from independent production company True Vision.

Among Klein's most recent commissions are a feature-length documentary marking the 20th anniversary of the publication of The Satanic Verses and the fatwa on author Sir Salman Rushdie; and Piers Morgan series The Dark Side of Fame.

One source said: "Richard is popular among independents and the BBC. He's the ideal candidate."

Sources say another contender is the BBC specialist factual commissioning editor for independents, Mark Bell.

Bell reports to Klein and was appointed to the role in February.

Before that, he was a channel executive across BBC2 and BBC4, during which time he was executive producer on BBC2's Summer of British Film season, as well as The Edwardians, Pop on Trial, The Lost Decade and Science Fiction Britannia on BBC4.

Other candidates include BBC in-house head of knowledge commissioning Emma Swain, More4 head Hamish Mykura, his predecessor, Peter Dale, and BBC commissioner for arts and religion Adam Kemp.

The BBC4 controller job was advertised last week, with a closing of this Sunday, October 26. A BBC spokesman declined to comment.
